https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/4055/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

@guozhangwang @ijuma I've been running this on a linux vm with 1 cpu and 2G of ram. I couldn't get it to fail but after lots of debugging etc, i saw it was just taking a long long time for stuff to flow through. This came down to the fact that we had a thread that was Producing as fast as it can while also trying to run a broker, zookeeper, n streams threads etc etc. Once i changed it to not use the thread and only produce one message for each key (which is all it needs to do), the run time came down from approx 2 minutes to approx 20 seconds
@dguy I can see how this simplifies things, but it should have worked with continuous producing too right?
@enothereska yes it does work, but the producing thread is too much on an underpowered machine. The test doesn't need to have continuous producing to prove that it works.

@ijuma do we know why is there so much (unpredictable) resource contention on Jenkins jobs? @dguy  I completely see your point. I'm worried that even with this change, due to the unpredictability of Jenkins, there is no tight guarantee this cannot happen again. @dguy does it make sense to reduce the timeouts back to some sane limit with this change (e.g., back to 30 secs)?

Thank @johnma14 . Btw: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4923 got merged yesterday, thus, the scope of this JIRA is enlarged by a few more configs we don't allow to overwrite if EOS is enabled. Can you please rebase to `trunk` and update this PR accordingly? Thanks a lot.
I think Yes :)

https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2994 fixed `shouldBeAbleToPerformMultipleTransactions`

`shouldNotViolateEosIfOneTaskFails` is still flaky -- it sometimes fails with
```
[2017-05-17 17:31:59,893] ERROR [Transaction Coordinator 0]: transactionalId: appId-1-0_0 -- Current state is Empty, but received transaction marker result: ABORT (kafka.coordinator.transaction.TransactionCoordinator:99)
[2017-05-17 17:31:59,895] ERROR aborting producer batches because the transaction manager is in an error state. (org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender:208)
org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: Unhandled error in EndTxnResponse: The producer attempted a transactional operation in an invalid state
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.TransactionManager$EndTxnHandler.handleResponse(TransactionManager.java:759)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.TransactionManager$TxnRequestHandler.onComplete(TransactionManager.java:529)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClientResponse.onComplete(ClientResponse.java:100)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.NetworkClient.poll(NetworkClient.java:378)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.run(Sender.java:196)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.run(Sender.java:152)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```

Other times it fails with:
```
Expected :<[KeyValue(0, 0), KeyValue(0, 1), KeyValue(0, 2), KeyValue(0, 3), KeyValue(0, 4), KeyValue(0, 5), KeyValue(0, 6), KeyValue(0, 7), KeyValue(0, 8), KeyValue(0, 9), KeyValue(0, 10), KeyValue(0, 11), KeyValue(0, 12), KeyValue(0, 13), KeyValue(0, 14), KeyValue(0, 15), KeyValue(0, 16), KeyValue(0, 17), KeyValue(0, 18), KeyValue(0, 19)]>
     
Actual   :<[KeyValue(0, 0), KeyValue(0, 1), KeyValue(0, 2), KeyValue(0, 3), KeyValue(0, 4), KeyValue(0, 5), KeyValue(0, 6), KeyValue(0, 7), KeyValue(0, 8), KeyValue(0, 9), KeyValue(0, 10), KeyValue(0, 11), KeyValue(0, 12), KeyValue(0, 13), KeyValue(0, 14), KeyValue(0, 10), KeyValue(0, 11), KeyValue(0, 12), KeyValue(0, 13), KeyValue(0, 14), KeyValue(0, 15), KeyValue(0, 16), KeyValue(0, 17), KeyValue(0, 18), KeyValue(0, 19)]>

	at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:20)
	at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:8)
	at org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.EosIntegrationTest.checkResultPerKey(EosIntegrationTest.java:234)
	at org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.EosIntegrationTest.shouldNotViolateEosIfOneTaskFails(EosIntegrationTest.java:527)
```
For this case, it read ABORTED data (ie, records with value `10` to `15`).

ping @dguy @hachikuji @apurvam @junrao for reviews.

Two major changes plus one minor change:

0) change `stateLock` to a read-write lock.

1) Put the check of "isCoordinator" and "coordinatorLoading" together with the return of the metadata, under one read lock block, since otherwise we can get incorrect behavior if there is a change in the metadata cache after the check but before the accessing of the metadata.

2) Grab the read lock right before trying to append to local txn log, and until the local append returns; this is to avoid the scenario that the epoch has actually changed when we are appending to local log (e.g. emigration followed by immigration).

3) Minor: enable reaper thread in the txn marker purgatory, since we are watching each delayed operation on two keys: txnId and partitionId, we need the reaper to purge these already completed items even though nothing will be expired.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4113/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).
@ijuma : Thanks for the updated patch. LGTM. I will let you merge it after the test passes.

One thing I realized while working on this PR is that, in purgatory's `cancelForKey` function, we only remove the elements from the watch-list but does not set its completed boolean; so if it is watched on other keys they will not be purged. I think this is a bug, that we should try-set its `completed` bit upon canceling it from `cancelForKey`?
@guozhangwang @mjsax thank you for reviewing, this is my first merge. I cannot wait to do more :)
